bibl.title: Ferdinand Marino and Carolina B. Marino v. D. H. McCalla.Return of Respondent
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.
NINTH JUDICIAL CIRCUIT; DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON.
In the matter of the petition of Ferdinand Marino and Carolina Beluscia Marino on behalf of Joseph Marino.
Return of Respondent, Writ of Habeas Corpus.
div1.p: To the Honorable C. H. Hanford, Judge of said Court.

The respondent, Lieutenant Commander H. T. Mayo, United States Navy, upon whom, as the Commanding Officer of the U. S. S. Wisconsin, as been served a Writ of Habeas Corpus to produce before your honorable Court Joseph Marino, an Ordinary Seaman in the United States Navy, respectfully makes return and states that he holds the said Joseph Marino under an enlistment as Landsman for Training, United States Navy, duly made by him, the said Joseph Marino, on board the U. S. R. S. Nipsic at Puget Sound Navy Yard, Washington, on December 7th, 1901, at which time and place he, the said Joseph Marino, took oath that his age at that time was eighteen years and one month, and this oath duly signed by him is now on file in the Bureau of Navigation, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.
He, the said Joseph Marino, was on the tenth day November, 1902, promoted from Landsman for Training to Ordinary Seaman.
A statement by the Commanding Officer of the U. S. R. S. Nipsic, Lieutenant Commander F. M. Bostwick, United States Navy, is attached to this return.

In obedience, however, to the said Writ of Habeas Corpus, the respondent herewith produces before the Court the body of the said Joseph Marino, and respectfully represents to the Honorable Court that if the Court find that the said Joseph Marino, Ordinary Seaman, United States Navy, was not, at the date of his enlistment, fully eighteen years of age, he, the said Joseph Marino, Ordinary Seaman, United States Navy, is liable to punishment by a Naval Court Martial for fraudulent enlistment. And the respondent respectfully prays the Court that, in such case, he, the said Joseph Marino, Ordinary Seaman, United States Navy, be returned to the custody of the respondent in order that steps may be taken to bring him before a Naval Court Martial.
div1.ab: H. T. Mayo, Lieutenant Commander, United States Navy. Commanding U.S.S. Wisconsin.
Dated on boad the U. S. S. Wisconsin, Puget Sound Navy Yard, Bremerton, Washington, January 5th, 1903.
U.S.R.S. Nipsic, Navy Yard, Puget Sound, January 3, 1903.
div1.p: Replying to your communication of the 3rd inst: Joseph Marino enlisted on board this vessel as a landsman for training on December 7th, 1901, giving his age as eighteen years one month. He took the oath, having been warned that if any of the statements he made were untrue, he would be liable to punishment for fraudulent enlistment.
Very Respetfully, F. M. Bostwick Lieut-Commander, U.S.N. Commanding.
div1.ab: U.S.R.S. Nipsic, Navy Yard, Puget Sound, January 3, 1903.
Bostwick, F. M. Lieut-Commander, U.S.N. Commanding.
div1.p: to case of Joseph Marino for training.
div1.ab: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT of the UNITED STATES.

Ferdinand Marino and Carolina Beluscia Marino
Petitioners,
vs.
Lt. Commander H.T. Mayo, U.S.N. Commanding U.S.S. Wisconsin, Respondent.
RETURN TO WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.

FILED IN THE U. S. CIRCUIT COURT, DIST. OF WASHINGTON.
JAN 5 1903 A. REEVES AYRES, Clerk
R M Hopkins Dep.
